'''Gaye Adegbalola''' (born '''Gaye Todd''', March 21, 1944, [[Fredericksburg, Virginia]], [[United States]])<ref name="billboard">[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/bio/index.jsp?pid=37581 Gaye Adegbalola], [[All Media Guide]] (2007). Retrieved on August 2, 2008.</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] singer and guitarist, teacher, lecturer, activist, and photographer.

==Biography==
Gaye's father, Clarence R. Todd, was the first [[African American|Black]] school board member in Fredericksburg and was also a jazz musician.<ref name="billboard"/> He later founded a performing arts group for black youth called "Souls of Shade", today known as Harambee 360.<ref name="HistoryPoint">Johnson, Virginia. [http://www.historypoint.org/af_am_people_places.asp African American History in the Rappahannock Region], [http://www.historypoint.org HistoryPoint.org]. Retrieved on August 2, 2008.</ref> Her mother, Gladys P. Todd, was one of the first organizers of the local [[civil rights movement]] in Fredericksburg, and also brought old [[jazz]] records home from her job at the Youth Canteen to give to the young Gaye.<ref name="HistoryPoint"/> Both parents were major influences on her music and social identity.

Gaye's surname, Adegbalola, was given to her by a [[Yoruba religion|Yoruba]] priest she met in 1968.<ref name="Article #22">Adegbalola, Gaye. [http://www.adegbalola.com/article22.html Article #22: What's The Difference Between Being Black And Being Gay???? ... When You're Black You Don't Have To Tell Your Mother], [http://www.adegbalola.com Adegbalola.com] (Spring 2004). Retrieved on August 2, 2008.</ref> Meaning "I am reclaiming my royalty," Adegbalola uses the name to signify her [[Black pride|pride]] in her black heritage.<ref name="Article #22"/><ref name="Gaye Ol' Time">Lehoczky, Etelka. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_2000_Feb_15/ai_59410461 Gaye Ol' Time - blues singers Gaye Adegbalola], [[The Advocate]] (February 15, 2000). Retrieved on August 1, 2008.</ref>

Gaye Todd graduated from high school as [[valedictorian]] in 1961, having already participated in numerous sit-in protests and picket lines as a member of the civil rights movement.<ref name="Nothing but the blues">Miller, Dan. [http://www.washblade.com/advertising/eTearsheets/05-28-2004/067.pdf Nothing but the blues], [[Washington Blade]] (May 28, 2004). Retrieved August 1, 2008.</ref> She later attended [[Boston University]], graduating with a B.A. in Biology.<ref name="Nothing but the blues"/> Gaye's occupations after college included those of a [[technical writer]] for [[TRW Inc.|TRW Systems]], a biochemical researcher at [[Rockefeller University]], and a [[bacteriologist]] at [[Harlem Hospital]], where she was also the local union representative.<ref name="bio">Adegbalola, Gaye. [http://www.adegbalola.com/bio.html Bio], [http://www.adegbalola.com Adegbalola.com]. Retrieved on August 2, 2008.</ref> These were all in sharp contrast to her first job as a teenager, working in a laundry for forty-five cents an hour.<ref name="bio"/>

From the years 1966 to 1970 she was involved in the [[Black Power Movement]] in New York and organized the Harlem Committee on Self-Defense.<ref name="bio"/> During this same period she met and married her husband. Her son, Juno Lumumba Kahlil was born in 1969, and would later make his own mark in the [[goth]]/[[industrial music]] world.<ref name="bio"/>

In 1970, after divorcing her husband, Gaye Adegbalola returned to Fredericksburg, where she taught science, gifted and talented, and creative thinking courses in the local schools.<ref name="bio"/> She helped her father direct the Harambee Theatre, sometimes acting in performances herself, until her father's death in 1977.<ref name="HistoryPoint"/> Having played the flute in her high school band, she began studying guitar in 1977.<ref name="NPR Saffire">Adegbalola, Gaye; Faye, Andra; Rabson, Ann. [[Neal Conan|Conan, Neal]]. [http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5366666 "Saffire, Uppity Blues Women"], [[National Public Radio|NPR]]: [[Talk of the Nation]] (April 27, 2006). Retrieved on August 1, 2008.</ref> In 1978 she received her Master of Education in Educational Media from [[Virginia State University]],<ref name="bio"/> and in 1982 was honored as Virginia's Teacher of the Year.<ref>[http://www.ccsso.org/projects/national_teacher_of_the_year/State_Teachers/1982/ 1982 State Teachers of the Year], [[Council of Chief State School Officers]] (June 26, 2008). Retrieved on August 2, 2008.</ref> She spent much of the rest of the eighties conducting teachers' workshops on motivational and teaching techniques.

Saffire - The Uppity Blues Women was first formed as a duo in 1984 by Ms. Adegbalola and her guitar teacher, Ann Rabson, with third member Earlene Lewis joining later to form a trio.<ref name="NPR Saffire"/> Lewis was replaced by Andra Faye in 1992. Saffire recorded their first album on their own label in 1987, ''Middle Age Blues'', with songs including "They Call Me Miss Thang," and "Middle Age Blues Boogie." The following year Gaye Adegbalola became a full-time blues performer and in 1990 the band recorded its first album for [[Alligator Records]], with Gaye winning the "Song of the Year" [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Award]] for "Middle Age Blues Boogie."<ref name="NPR Saffire"/> In 1991, she met her life partner, Suzanne Moe.<ref name="Nothing but the blues"/>

During the 1990s Gaye Adegbalola held workshops on various aspects of blues music and worked as a blues music reporter for the World Cafe program on [[National Public Radio]]. She also won a battle against cancer. In 1998 she co-founded the Steering Committee of the [[Blues Music Association]].  Her first solo album, ''Bitter Sweet Blues'', was recorded in 1999.   In addition to her own original compositions ("You Don't Have to Take It (Like I Did)"; "Big Ovaries, Baby"; and "Nothing's Changed") the album featured covers of songs by [[Bessie Smith]], [[Smokey Robinson]], [[Ma Rainey]], and [[Nina Simone]]. In 2000, in a short piece on her work and career in ''[[The Advocate]]'', Adegbalola came out as a [[lesbian]].<ref name="Gaye Ol' Time"/>

Adegbalola's song "Middle Aged Blues Boogie" was named Best Song of the Year at the 1990 W. C. Handy Awards (now the [[Blues Music Awards]]). Adegbalola was nominated for two Outmusic awards in 2005.<ref name="Gaye Blues">Shapiro, Gregg. [http://www.outsmartmagazine.com/cms-this_issue/200603--The+Gaye+Blues.html?PHPSESSID=fbb8b6e6b70c3fedea46 The Gaye Blues : Out blues singer Gaye Adegbalola releases a new compilation], OutSmart (March 2006). Retrieved on August 1, 2008.</ref> Adegbalola's song "Big Ovaries, Baby" is featured in episode 23 of [[The War On Democracy!]] [[podcast]].  [[Saffire - The Uppity Blues Women]] disbanded amicably in 2009, but Adegbalola continues to pursue solo projects.<ref>Gaye Adegbalola: The OUTmusic Interview] by Jeremy Gloff [appeared on OUTmusic’s Myspace Page November 15th, 2008]  "Q 3) what’s your fave song that you have ever written? A. It is usually the one I am presently working on — what I’m closest to at the moment. However, I’ll name my favorite that I just recorded: “I Can Do Bad All By Myself.” The one that brought me the most money is one that put my son through college: “The Middle Aged Blues Boogie.”</ref>
